FedCiR: Client-Invariant Representation Learning for Federated Non-IID Features

Zijian Li, , Zehong Lin, ,
Jiawei Shao, , Yuyi Mao, , Jun Zhang Z. Li, Z. Lin, J. Shao, and J. Zhang are with the Department of Electronic and Computer Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong, China (E-mail: {zijian.li, jiawei.shao}@connect.ust.hk, {eezhlin, eejzhang}@ust.hk). Y. Mao is with the Department of Electrical and Electronic, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, China (E-mail: yuyi-eie.mao@polyu.edu.hk) (Corresponding author: Zehong Lin.)
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed learning paradigm that maximizes the potential of data-driven models for edge devices without sharing their raw data. However, devices often have non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data, meaning their local data distributions can vary significantly. The heterogeneity in input data distributions across devices, commonly referred to as the feature shift problem, can adversely impact the training convergence and accuracy of the global model. To analyze the intrinsic causes of the feature shift problem, we develop a generalization error bound in FL, which motivates us to propose FedCiR, a client-invariant representation learning framework that enables clients to extract informative and client-invariant features. Specifically, we improve the mutual information term between representations and labels to encourage representations to carry essential classification knowledge, and diminish the mutual information term between the client set and representations conditioned on labels to promote representations of clients to be client-invariant. We further incorporate two regularizers into the FL framework to bound the mutual information terms with an approximate global representation distribution to compensate for the absence of the ground-truth global representation distribution, thus achieving informative and client-invariant feature extraction. To achieve global representation distribution approximation, we propose a data-free mechanism performed by the server without compromising privacy. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving client-invariant representation learning and solving the data heterogeneity issue.

Index Terms:
Representation learning, federated learning (FL), non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data, edge intelligence.

1 Introduction

With the ever-increasing popularity and deployment of edge devices, there is a tremendous amount of data generated by users on a daily basis. These data hold valuable insights that can be utilized to enhance various artificial intelligence (AI) applications and services. However, with the increasing privacy concerns as well as the enormous communication costs, reckless data collection and centralized training are no longer acceptable. Serving as an efficient and privacy-preserving training paradigm, federated learning (FL) enables distributed devices to collaboratively train a global model without revealing their private data. The classical FL approach, represented by FedAvg [1], has successfully demonstrated its potential in edge-AI tasks, such as autonomous driving [2], virtual reality (VR) services [3], and unmanned aerial vehicle control [4].

One major obstacle to efficient FL is the data heterogeneity among devices, i.e., the data across devices are non-independently and identically distributed (non-IID). It has been verified that FL algorithms often suffer from degraded accuracy and slow convergence with non-IID data, which are inherently caused by deflected local updates and local optima [5, 6, 7]. The non-IID issue in FL can be classified into two categories: label shift and feature shift [8]. Label shift arises when clients have different distributions of class labels, even if the input feature space is the same. Feature shift, on the other hand, occurs when the underlying distributions of input features vary across clients, despite having a common label space. In this work, we focus on the feature shift problem [9], which typically arises in healthcare [10] and wildlife protection applications [11] because of the device and environmental discrepancy. For example, in wildlife protection applications where the cameras are placed in different locations to capture images of wildlife, the images from these cameras are different in tonality, rendering them skewed in features. These discrepancies are primarily caused by distinct environmental conditions like weather and illumination levels.

To solve the feature shift problem in FL, many studies proposed to introduce local constraints with the knowledge of the global model or gradient information for clients, whereby the discrepancy between local updates is mitigated. These methods, however, focused on the algorithmic aspect and only achieved limited performance gains with heavy data heterogeneity [12]. Meanwhile, another stream of studies endeavored to solve the feature-shift issue through synthetic data augmentation [13, 14, 15, 16], but sharing extra synthetic data among clients inevitably leads to data privacy leakage. In addition, explicit feature alignment among clients is another effective technique to solve the feature shift problem [17, 18]. By sharing and aggregating local features as global features, clients can align the local features with the global features, thereby reaching a common feature space for solving the feature shift problem. Nevertheless, the local features remain susceptible to overfitting with heterogeneous data distributions, resulting in biased global features after aggregation.

The feature shift problem has been extensively studied in classical centralized training, particularly in the context of domain adaptation and domain generalization [19, 20], which aim to transfer the knowledge of labeled source domains to a different target domain. Many studies have established the generalization error bounds of the target domain on the source domains, using the source risk and the discrepancy between source and target domains. These bounds provide sufficient conditions to reduce the error on the domain dataset and thus address the centralized feature-skewed issue. Consequently, many works [21, 22] have employed domain-invariant representation learning to reduce the generalization bound for better domain adaptation and generalization. However, the bounds derived in centralized settings are incompatible with FL since the source domains are distributed across clients. With private distributed data, all the existing domain-invariant representation methods for domain adaptation lose their effectiveness without the access to all the data domains during the training process. Therefore, it is critical to analyze the intrinsic causes of the feature-skewed issue in FL and propose effective methods to address it accordingly.

In this work, we first develop a generalization error bound for the global mixture dataset on local datasets in FL, which identifies two key factors for addressing the feature shift issue: the empirical local risks and the ℋℋ\mathcal{H}-divergence between global and local datasets. Motivated by this analysis, we propose a federated client-invariant representation learning algorithm, called FedCiR, to reduce the generalization error bound by encouraging local models to extract informative and client-invariant features from an information-theoretic perspective. Specifically, FedCiR introduces two mutual information terms. The first term promotes features to be informative by maximizing the mutual information between representations and labels, which addresses the information-insufficient issue in local models caused by the limited data. The second term diminishes the mutual information between the client set and representations conditioned on labels, which advances representations across clients to be client-invariant. To integrate these mutual information objectives into FL, we develop two regularizers that bound the objectives using an approximate global representation distribution. Such an approximation is needed since the ground truth distribution is unknown in FL. To achieve this approximation without compromising privacy, we propose a novel data-free mechanism using a generator, which is trained to maximize the consensus between local classifiers at the server. The first proposed regularization enhances the global view for local client representations, while the second explicitly aligns global and local distributions, ensuring representations retain just the client-invariant information needed. Figure 1 depicts the main idea of the proposed method. The main contributions of this work are summarized as follows:

  • •

    To provide a theoretical foundation for addressing the non-IID issue in FL, we establish a generalization error bound between the global and local datasets, which motivates us to propose a federated client-invariant representation learning algorithm, called FedCiR.

  • •

    We propose two mutual information terms to achieve informative and client-invariant representation extraction, respectively, and introduce two regularization terms based on an approximate global representation distribution to bound the mutual information terms, which can be employed in FL and encourages local representations to capture more label-discriminative and client-invariant information.

  • •

    We propose a data-free mechanism to approximate the global representation distribution by using a generative network to ensure the consistency of local classifiers at the server, which protects the privacy as strict as FedAvg.

  • •

    We conduct extensive experiments on benchmark and real-world datasets, which demonstrate that FedCiR consistently outperforms baselines in accuracy without introducing additional overhead for clients, and confirm its effectiveness in client-invariant representation learning.

Organization: The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we review the related works on the non-IID problem in FL and domain-invariant representation learning. Section 3 describes the feature shift problem in FL, and Section 4 illustrates the fundamental causes of the feature shift problem with a federated generalization error bound. We propose a class-discriminative and client-invariant representation learning method for FL (FedCiR) and a data-free mechanism for global representation distribution approximation to achieve FedCiR in Section 5. We evaluate FedCiR via extensive simulations in Section 6. Finally, we conclude the paper in Section 7.

2 Related Works

FL under data heterogeneity: FL was originally proposed by McMahan et al. [1] as a distributed training paradigm to train a global model without disclosing local private data. However, the statistical heterogeneity, which adversely affects the convergence and accuracy performance [6, 7], quickly emerged as a major obstacle in FL. To address this issue, many works added proximal terms to regularize local objective functions with the global knowledge [23, 5, 24, 25]. For instance, FedProx [25] included a regularizer into local training to force the local updates to get close to the global model. FedDyn [23] proposed a dynamic regularizer for each client to ensure the consistency between the stationary points of local and global empirical loss. In addition, MOON [24] utilized contrastive learning to reduce the distance between representations output by the global and local models to correct the local training. These methods, however, cannot fundamentally eliminate the data heterogeneity and may encounter the performance bottleneck in extreme cases with highly heterogeneous data distributions [12].

Moreover, instead of pushing local parameters to trace the global parameters, some methods [17, 26, 18] attempted to align the intermediate features between clients through the global prototypes, which are computed by averaging the features for each class locally and aggregating them among clients at the server. However, the local prototypes suffer from overfitting problems with data heterogeneity, and naively aggregating them leads to imprecise global prototypes. In contrast, this work aims to align the representation distributions of clients with a global representation distribution, which is approximated by maximizing the consensus among local classifiers due to its absence in FL, thus improving training stability and efficiency.

Another research line for data heterogeneity relies on data augmentation [27, 28]. Many studies attempted to generate and share synthetic data using a generative model [29, 14, 15] or a mixup mechanism [30]. Nevertheless, recklessly sharing synthetic samples raises extra privacy concerns. To mitigate potential privacy leakage, recent approaches have developed data-free knowledge distillation mechanisms to generate auxiliary data with a generative model at the server, which can be used for global model calibration [31] and local model updating [32, 13]. These methods, however, required clients to upload the training data distributions to the server to optimize the feature generator, which is excessively vulnerable to gradient inversion attacks [33]. Different from them, we utilize the ensemble predictions of local classifiers to train the feature generator without extra local information leakage. More importantly, we further utilize the generator to estimate the global representation distribution for client-invariant representation extraction, which benefits solving the feature shift problem.

Domain-invariant representation learning: Domain-invariant representation learning has been proven effective for domain adaptation and generalization by reducing the discrepancy between source and target domains [34]. Adversarial learning is a widely used mechanism to learn the domain-invariant features by gradually disentangling the irrelevant and domain-specific features via additional discriminators [21, 35, 36]. The adversarial networks are able to push representation distributions of different domains to be the same, thereby enabling domain-invariant representation learning. FedADA [37] and FedADG [38] adopted this technique to effectively solve domain adaptation and domain generalization problems, respectively, in FL. However, due to the limited domains of data in each device, they demanded to train additional generators to generate the lacking domains of data for adversarial training, which aggravates the computation burden for devices.

Another stream of methods for domain-invariant representation learning is explicit feature distribution alignment [39, 22, 40], which can be achieved by minimizing the distance between source and target distributions [41, 42, 43]. However, these methods require the access to all the domains of data during the training process and thus are incompatible with FL. A recent work FedSR [44] used probabilistic networks to approximate feature distributions for clients and aligned them via iterative local updating and global aggregation. Nevertheless, FedSR is sensitive to the client number and suffers from the local overfitting problem due to the distinct divergence of deterministic networks between clients caused by the non-IID data. Instead, this work approximates the global representation distribution with the ensemble predictions of local models at the server, thus improving the stability and effectiveness of feature distribution alignment.

We adopt 𝒙,y𝒙𝑦\bm{x},y, and 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} to represent the corresponding instances of random variables. The goal of FL is to train a global model 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} that minimizes the expected risks for clients as follows:

In the classical FedAvg method [1], the optimization of the model 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} is achieved through a collaborative effort between clients over 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} communication rounds. In each communication round t∈[𝒯]𝑡delimited-[]𝒯t\in[\mathcal{T}], a subset of clients 𝒦t⊆𝒦subscript𝒦𝑡𝒦\mathcal{K}_{t}\subseteq\mathcal{K} are randomly selected by the server and download the global model 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}_{t} for local training. Due to the impracticality of calculating full gradients on the entire local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}, each active client k∈𝒦t𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡k\in\mathcal{K}_{t} performs local model updates with E𝐸E local steps using the mini-batch stochastic gradient descent (SGD). To be specific, in each local step e∈[E]𝑒delimited-[]𝐸e\in[E] of the t𝑡t-th communication round, client k𝑘k randomly samples a batch of training data ξkt,esuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑡𝑒\xi_{k}^{t,e} and updates local model 𝒘kt,e−1superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑡𝑒1\bm{w}_{k}^{t,e-1} with the gradients ∇ℓ​(𝒘kt,e−1;ξkt,e)∇ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑡𝑒1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑡𝑒\nabla\ell(\bm{w}_{k}^{t,{e-1}};\xi_{k}^{t,e}) as follows:

Afterwards, the new global model 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1} is broadcast to the newly active clients for the next round of training.

Despite the success of FL in many practical applications, the heterogeneous data distributions, including label-skewed and feature-skewed distributions, still compromise the training performance in terms of convergence and accuracy [12, 7]. In this work, we aim at addressing the federated feature-skewed problem, where the clients have varying input distributions (domains) for a given label class ycsubscript𝑦𝑐y_{c}, i.e., p​(𝒙|k,yc)≠p​(𝒙|k′,yc)𝑝conditional𝒙𝑘subscript𝑦𝑐𝑝conditional𝒙superscript𝑘′subscript𝑦𝑐p(\bm{x}|k,y_{c})\neq p(\bm{x}|k^{\prime},y_{c}), where k,k′∈𝒦𝑘superscript𝑘′𝒦k,k^{\prime}\in\mathcal{K} and k≠k′𝑘superscript𝑘′k\neq k^{\prime}. Feature-skewed problems often arise in edge AI applications due to the variations in natural conditions and processing methodologies across edge devices. For example, the images taken by smartphones in a rural area may be different from those taken by smartphones in an urban area. With the feature distribution shift among clients, traditional FL methods, like FedAvg, attempt to learn all possible feature knowledge, including client-invariant and client-specific knowledge, during local training. However, the client-specific knowledge causes representation divergence, i.e., p​(𝒛|k,y,𝒙)≠p​(𝒛|k′,y,𝒙)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝒙𝑝conditional𝒛superscript𝑘′𝑦𝒙p(\bm{z}|k,y,\bm{x})\neq p(\bm{z}|k^{\prime},y,\bm{x}), leading to an accuracy reduction. Although many studies have proposed to alleviate the feature shift issue by reducing the divergence of local models [27], guidelines that can fundamentally solve this problem still remain unclear.

4 Generalization Error Bound for Federated Learning

To analyze the fundamental causes of the federated feature-skewed problem, in this section, we first introduce a generalization error bound in domain adaptation [20], which is able to solve the feature shift problem in centralized training by minimizing the generalization error on the target domain. Afterwards, we extend this bound for FL, which motivates us to develop a label-discriminative and client-invariant representation learning method in Section 5.

To ensure clarity and enhance understanding, following [20], we supplement some relevant definitions before delving into the analysis.

Definition 1.

(Hypothesis 𝐡𝐡{\bm{h}}) Let 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} be a one-hot vector set that contains N𝑁N one-hot vectors for an N𝑁N-class classification task. Given a sample 𝐱∈𝒳𝐱𝒳\bm{x}\in\mathcal{X}, a hypothesis 𝐡:𝒳→𝒱:𝐡→𝒳𝒱\bm{h}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{V} outputs the one-hot vector 𝐯∈𝒱𝐯𝒱\bm{v}\in\mathcal{V} with 𝐯c=1subscript𝐯𝑐1\bm{v}_{c}=1 and 𝐯j=0,j≠cformulae-sequencesubscript𝐯𝑗0𝑗𝑐\bm{v}_{j}=0,j\neq c to represent the class label c∈[N]𝑐delimited-[]𝑁c\in[N].

Definition 2.

(Domain ⟨𝒟,𝐫⟩𝒟𝐫\langle\mathcal{D},\bm{r}\rangle) We define ⟨𝒟,𝐫⟩𝒟𝐫\langle\mathcal{D},\bm{r}\rangle as a domain, where 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is a data distribution over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and 𝐫:𝒳→𝒱:𝐫→𝒳𝒱\bm{r}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{V} represents its ground-truth labeling function.

Definition 3.

(Conditional function class 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} on ℋℋ\mathcal{H}) For a function class ℋ⊆[0,1]𝒳ℋsuperscript01𝒳{\mathcal{H}}\subseteq[0,1]^{\mathcal{X}} on the input space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, we define a function class 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} conditioned on ℋℋ\mathcal{H} for the hypotheses 𝐠𝐠\bm{g}, and 𝐠​(𝐱)≔sign​(|𝐡​(𝐱)−𝐡′​(𝐱)|−m)≔𝐠𝐱sign𝐡𝐱superscript𝐡′𝐱𝑚\bm{g}(\bm{x})\coloneqq\text{sign}(|\bm{h}(\bm{x})-\bm{h}^{\prime}(\bm{x})|-m) with 𝐡,𝐡′∈ℋ𝐡superscript𝐡′ℋ{\bm{h}},{\bm{h}}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{H}} and 0≤m≤10𝑚10\leq m\leq 1.

Definition 4.

(𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}-divergence) Given the function class 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} and any two distributions 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, the 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}-divergence between the distributions of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} is defined as d𝒢​(𝒟,𝒟′)=sup𝐠∈𝒢|Pr𝒟⁡[𝐠​(𝐱)=1]−Pr𝒟′⁡[𝐠​(𝐱)=1]|subscript𝑑𝒢𝒟superscript𝒟′subscriptsupremum𝐠𝒢subscriptPr𝒟𝐠𝐱1subscriptPrsuperscript𝒟′𝐠𝐱1d_{\mathcal{G}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})=\sup_{\bm{g}\in\mathcal{G}}|\Pr_{\mathcal{D}}[\bm{g}(\bm{x})=1]-\Pr_{\mathcal{D}^{\prime}}[\bm{g}(\bm{x})=1]|.

The error bound in Theorem 1 reveals the intrinsic causes of the feature-skewed issue in terms of the source risk, distribution discrepancy between the source and target domains, and labeling function distance between the source and target domains in domain adaptation. To reduce the discrepancy between source and target domains, some studies [22, 41] proposed to learn an encoder 𝒘1:𝒳→𝒵:subscript𝒘1→𝒳𝒵\bm{w}_{1}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Z} to map the source distribution 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and target distribution 𝒟Tsubscript𝒟𝑇\mathcal{D}_{T} to a common representation distribution ℛℛ\mathcal{R} over 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} such that the induced representations of source and target domains are closer and thereby better classified by a new hypothesis 𝒉^:𝒵→𝒱:^𝒉→𝒵𝒱\hat{\bm{h}}:\mathcal{Z}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}.

However, in FL, the target distribution refers to the global mixture distribution among all the clients, i.e., 𝒟~=𝒟T=∪{𝒟k}k∈𝒦~𝒟subscript𝒟𝑇subscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑘𝒦\tilde{\mathcal{D}}=\mathcal{D}_{T}=\cup\{\mathcal{D}_{k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{K}}, which leads to a global representation distribution ℛ~=∪{ℛk}k∈𝒦~ℛsubscriptsubscriptℛ𝑘𝑘𝒦\tilde{\mathcal{R}}=\cup\{\mathcal{R}_{k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{K}}. Following prior works [39, 20, 45], we assume that the data distribution among clients is covariate shift, i.e., the labeling functions among clients are the same, leading to a global labeling function 𝒓~:=𝒓k=𝒓k′assign~𝒓subscript𝒓𝑘subscript𝒓superscript𝑘′\tilde{\bm{r}}\vcentcolon=\bm{r}_{k}=\bm{r}_{k^{\prime}}, where k,k′∈𝒦𝑘superscript𝑘′𝒦k,k^{\prime}\in\mathcal{K} and k≠k′𝑘superscript𝑘′k\neq k^{\prime}. This is reasonable because, for example, a dog image is annotated as “dog” according to the same criteria based on its shape and outline, even if at different clients. Furthermore, the source domains are distributed across clients and cannot be shared with each other. To establish the connection between the source and target representations w.r.t. the hypothesis 𝒉^^𝒉\hat{\bm{h}}, we derive an error bound for FL in the following theorem.

Theorem 2.

(Federated generalization error bound) Let ⟨𝒟k,𝐫k⟩subscript𝒟ksubscript𝐫k\langle\mathcal{D}_{k},\bm{r}_{k}\rangle and ⟨𝒟~,𝐫~⟩~𝒟~𝐫\langle\tilde{\mathcal{D}},\tilde{\bm{r}}\rangle be the domain of client kkk and global domain in the FL setting, respectively. For any convex function class ℋ^⊆[0,1]𝒵^ℋsuperscript01𝒵\hat{\mathcal{H}}\subseteq[0,1]^{\mathcal{Z}}, convex risk function ε​(⋅)ε⋅\varepsilon(\cdot), and ∀𝐡^∈ℋ^for-all^𝐡^ℋ\forall\hat{\bm{h}}\in\hat{\mathcal{H}}, the following inequality holds:

ε​(𝒉^)≤∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​εk​(𝒉^k)+∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​d𝒢^​(ℛk,ℛ~),𝜀^𝒉subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝜀𝑘subscript^𝒉𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝑑^𝒢subscriptℛ𝑘~ℛ\displaystyle\varepsilon(\hat{\bm{h}})\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\varepsilon_{{k}}(\hat{\bm{h}}_{k})+\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)d_{\hat{\mathcal{G}}}(\mathcal{R}_{k},\tilde{\mathcal{R}}), (7)

where 𝒢^^𝒢\hat{\mathcal{G}} is defined as the function class conditioned on ℋ^^ℋ\hat{\mathcal{H}} for the hypotheses 𝐠^^𝐠\hat{\bm{g}} that 𝐠^​(𝐳)≔sign​(|𝐡^​(𝐳)−𝐡^′​(𝐳)|−m)≔^𝐠𝐳sign^𝐡𝐳superscript^𝐡′𝐳𝑚\hat{\bm{g}}(\bm{z})\coloneqq\text{sign}(|\hat{\bm{h}}(\bm{z})-\hat{\bm{h}}^{\prime}(\bm{z})|-m) with 𝐡^,𝐡^′∈ℋ^^𝐡superscript^𝐡′^ℋ{\hat{\bm{h}}},{\hat{\bm{h}}}^{\prime}\in{\hat{\mathcal{H}}} and 0≤m≤10𝑚10\leq m\leq 1, and ℛksubscriptℛ𝑘\mathcal{R}_{k} and ℛ~~ℛ\tilde{\mathcal{R}} are the induced representation distributions of 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} and 𝒟~~𝒟\tilde{\mathcal{D}}, respectively.

Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

Theorem 2 holds when the hypothesis 𝒉^^𝒉\hat{\bm{h}} and loss function ε​(⋅)𝜀⋅\varepsilon(\cdot) are both convex. In general, for classification tasks in FL, we can adopt the last fully-connected layer followed by a softmax layer as the classifier and the cross-entropy loss as the loss function, which are both convex, such that Theorem 2 is valid. Compared with the error bounds in [37] and [13] that require the impractical joint error of the optimal hypothesis w.r.t. source and target domains, the generalization error bound derived in Theorem 2 characterizes the sufficient conditions to relieve the feature-skewed issue in FL. Specifically, the first term represents the expected source errors of clients, and the second term quantifies the marginal representation distribution distance between source and target domains.

According to Theorem 2, we can reduce the risks of the global dataset by minimizing the local source errors and marginal distribution distance between global and local datasets, thereby solving the feature-skewed issue. To achieve this goal, we propose a novel FL algorithm that learns label-discriminative and client-invariant representations in the next section. The client-invariant representation learning is effective since it achieves smaller divergence between the global and local datasets in the feature space (the second term in Theorem 2), which further reduces the discrepancy between global and local models and achieves lower local risks (the first term in Theorem 2) in local training. This will be verified by experiments in Section 6.4.

5 Proposed Method

In this section, we propose a method called FedCiR to achieve label-discriminative and client-invariant representation extraction and reduce the generalization error for FL. Specifically, we propose two mutual information terms to promote the representations to be class-discriminative and client-invariant, respectively. Moreover, two local regularizers are incorporated into FL to bound these two mutual information terms with an approximate global representation distribution. To achieve the approximation, we further develop a data-free mechanism by maximizing the consensus of the uploaded classifiers, which protects the privacy as strict as FedAvg.

5.1 Class-Discriminative Representation Learning for Federated Learning

In the proposed representation learning framework, we aim to learn the representation 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} of a data sample 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} with a distribution p𝒘1​(𝒛|𝒙)subscript𝑝subscript𝒘1conditional𝒛𝒙p_{\bm{w}_{1}}(\bm{z}|\bm{x}) parameterized by an encoder network 𝒘1subscript𝒘1\bm{w}_{1} (we omit 𝒘1subscript𝒘1\bm{w}_{1} afterwards for notation simplicity). With the usage of batch normalization (BN) layers, the representation distribution p​(𝒛|𝒙)𝑝conditional𝒛𝒙p(\bm{z}|\bm{x}) is assumed to be a normal distribution, which can be computed through a probabilistic mapping: p​(𝒛|𝒙)=𝒩​(𝒛;𝝁𝒘1​(𝒙),𝝈𝒘1​(𝒙))𝑝conditional𝒛𝒙𝒩𝒛subscript𝝁subscript𝒘1𝒙subscript𝝈subscript𝒘1𝒙p(\bm{z}|\bm{x})=\mathcal{N}(\bm{z};\bm{\mu}_{\bm{w}_{1}}(\bm{x}),\bm{\sigma}_{\bm{w}_{1}}(\bm{x})), where 𝝁𝒘1​(⋅)subscript𝝁subscript𝒘1⋅\bm{\mu}_{\bm{w}_{1}}(\cdot) and 𝝈𝒘1​(⋅)subscript𝝈subscript𝒘1⋅\bm{\sigma}_{\bm{w}_{1}}(\cdot) are the mean and standard deviation matrices output by the encoder network 𝒘1subscript𝒘1\bm{w}_{1}. By using the reparameterization trick [46], we obtain p​(𝒛|𝒙)​d​𝒛=p​(ϵ)​d​ϵ𝑝conditional𝒛𝒙𝑑𝒛𝑝bold-italic-ϵ𝑑bold-italic-ϵp(\bm{z}|\bm{x})d\bm{z}=p(\bm{\epsilon})d\bm{\epsilon}, where 𝒛=f​(𝒙,ϵ)𝒛𝑓𝒙bold-italic-ϵ\bm{z}=f(\bm{x},\bm{\epsilon}) is a deterministic function of 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} and ϵ∼𝒩​(0,𝑰)similar-tobold-italic-ϵ𝒩0𝑰\bm{\epsilon}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\bm{I}) is a Gaussian random variable. As a result, the noise term ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon} becomes independent of the parameters 𝒘1subscript𝒘1\bm{w}_{1}, which makes it convenient to compute gradients and update parameters.

During the FL training process, we sample the representation 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} for a given 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} from the distribution p​(𝒛|𝒙)𝑝conditional𝒛𝒙p(\bm{z}|\bm{x}). After obtaining the representation 𝒛𝒛\bm{z}, we train a classifier 𝒘2subscript𝒘2\bm{w}_{2} that predicts the label y𝑦y with a predictive distribution p^𝒘2​(y|𝒛)subscript^𝑝subscript𝒘2conditional𝑦𝒛\hat{p}_{\bm{w}_{2}}(y|\bm{z}) (we also omit the parameters 𝒘2subscript𝒘2\bm{w}_{2} afterwards). For general classification tasks, the predictive distribution is the output of a softmax layer that follows a linear layer. Therefore, the predictive distribution of y𝑦y for 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} is given by:

p^​(y|𝒙)=𝔼p​(𝒛|𝒙)​p^​(y|𝒛).^𝑝conditional𝑦𝒙subscript𝔼𝑝conditional𝒛𝒙^𝑝conditional𝑦𝒛\hat{p}(y|\bm{x})=\mathbb{E}_{p(\bm{z}|\bm{x})}\hat{p}(y|\bm{z}). (8)

The loss function of sample 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} and label y𝑦y is set as the negative log predictive density, i.e., ℓ​(𝒘;𝒙,y)=−log⁡𝔼p​(𝒛|𝒙)​p^​(y|𝒛)ℓ𝒘𝒙𝑦subscript𝔼𝑝conditional𝒛𝒙^𝑝conditional𝑦𝒛\ell(\bm{w};\bm{x},y)=-\log\mathbb{E}_{p(\bm{z}|\bm{x})}\hat{p}(y|\bm{z}), where 𝒘=𝒘1∘𝒘2𝒘subscript𝒘1subscript𝒘2\bm{w}=\bm{w}_{1}\circ\bm{w}_{2} is the global model. With the local data distribution p​(𝒙,y|k)𝑝𝒙conditional𝑦𝑘p(\bm{x},y|k) and prediction distribution p^​(y|k,𝒛)^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛\hat{p}({y}|k,\bm{z}), the local objective function of client k𝑘k is given by:

ℒk=𝔼p​(𝒙,y|k)​[−log⁡𝔼p​(𝒛|𝒙)​p^​(y|k,𝒛)].subscriptℒ𝑘subscript𝔼𝑝𝒙conditional𝑦𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑝conditional𝒛𝒙^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛\mathcal{L}_{k}=\mathbb{E}_{p(\bm{x},y|k)}[-\log\mathbb{E}_{p(\bm{z}|\bm{x})}\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z})]. (9)

Recall that the joint distribution of FL is p​(k,y,𝒙)=p​(k)​p​(𝒙,y|k)𝑝𝑘𝑦𝒙𝑝𝑘𝑝𝒙conditional𝑦𝑘p(k,y,\bm{x})=p(k)p(\bm{x},y|k). Thus, the global objective function ℒf​lsubscriptℒ𝑓𝑙\mathcal{L}_{fl} is given by:

ℒf​l=∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​𝔼p​(𝒙,y|k)​[−log⁡𝔼p​(𝒛|𝒙)​p^​(y|k,𝒛)].subscriptℒ𝑓𝑙subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝔼𝑝𝒙conditional𝑦𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑝conditional𝒛𝒙^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{fl}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\mathbb{E}_{p(\bm{x},y|k)}[-\log\mathbb{E}_{p(\bm{z}|\bm{x})}\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z})]. (10)

The goal of representation learning in FL is to obtain informative representation Z𝑍Z that are useful for classifying their corresponding label Y𝑌Y. Note that Z𝑍Z and Y𝑌Y are global random variables defined over all the clients. However, the objective function ℒf​lsubscriptℒ𝑓𝑙\mathcal{L}_{fl} for representation learning only aims to improve the local partial knowledge for local models as in the traditional FL framework. This is because each client k𝑘k has access to only a local representation 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} that is sampled from p​(𝒛|𝒙)𝑝conditional𝒛𝒙p(\bm{z}|\bm{x}) given 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}, which leads to insufficient knowledge in local models.

To improve the label knowledge of representations, an intuitive method is to maximize the mutual information between representation Z𝑍Z and label Y𝑌Y, which is defined by I​(Y;Z)=∫Y∫Zp​(y,𝒛)​log​p​(y,𝒛)p​(y)​p​(𝒛)​𝑑𝒛​𝑑y𝐼𝑌𝑍subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑦𝒛log𝑝𝑦𝒛𝑝𝑦𝑝𝒛differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦I(Y;Z)=\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(y,\bm{z})\text{log}\frac{p(y,\bm{z})}{p(y)p(\bm{z})}d\bm{z}dy. Nevertheless, computing the mutual information term I​(Y;Z)𝐼𝑌𝑍I(Y;Z) during local training is intractable since the absence of the global representation distribution p​(𝒛|y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦p(\bm{z}|y) leads to the intractability of p​(y,𝒛)=p​(y)​p​(𝒛|y)𝑝𝑦𝒛𝑝𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦p(y,\bm{z})=p(y)p(\bm{z}|y). To overcome this issue, we derive an upper bound on the negative mutual information term in the following proposition by introducing an approximate variational distribution q​(𝒛|y)𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦q(\bm{z}|y) parameterized by a generative neural network 𝒘gsubscript𝒘𝑔\bm{w}_{g}, which will be detailed in Section 5.3.

Proposition 1.

Let q​(𝐳|y)𝑞conditional𝐳𝑦q(\bm{z}|y) be the approximation of the global representation distribution p​(𝐳|y)𝑝conditional𝐳𝑦p(\bm{z}|y). The negative mutual information −I​(Y;Z)𝐼𝑌𝑍-I(Y;Z) is upper bounded as follows:

−I​(Y;Z)≤ℒr​e​g,𝐼𝑌𝑍subscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔\displaystyle-I(Y;Z)\leq\mathcal{L}_{reg}, (11)

where

ℒr​e​g=∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​𝔼p​(y)​𝔼q​(𝒛|y)​[−log⁡p^​(y|k,𝒛)].subscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝔼𝑝𝑦subscript𝔼𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦delimited-[]^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{reg}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\mathbb{E}_{p(y)}\mathbb{E}_{q(\bm{z}|y)}[-\log\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z})]. (12)
Proof.

See Appendix B. ∎

Note that the upper bound ℒr​e​gsubscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔\mathcal{L}_{reg} in Proposition 1 can be adopted as a regularizer in FL directly. As such, we adopt ℒr​e​gsubscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔\mathcal{L}_{reg} as the proxy of the negative mutual information −I​(Y;Z)𝐼𝑌𝑍-I(Y;Z) and focus on decreasing ℒr​e​gsubscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔\mathcal{L}_{reg} to minimize the negative mutual information −I​(Y;Z)𝐼𝑌𝑍-I(Y;Z). Specifically, in each communication round, each client downloads the generative neural network 𝒘gsubscript𝒘𝑔\bm{w}_{g} from the server and uses it to output the global representations 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} given any class label y𝑦y and Gaussian noise ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon}. By including these global representations 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} in the local updating, clients can obtain more label information for representations.

5.2 Client-Invariant Representation Learning for Federated Learning

Under the feature-skewed scenarios in FL, training an encoder 𝒘1subscript𝒘1\bm{w}_{1} that can extract client-invariant representations is non-trivial with distributed domains of data. To address this problem, we introduce another regularization term to facilitate the extraction of client-invariant representation.

Intuitively, if the representation distribution of each class is the same among clients, i.e., p​(𝒛|k,y)=p​(𝒛|k′,y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛superscript𝑘′𝑦p(\bm{z}|k,y)=p(\bm{z}|k^{\prime},y), ∀k,k′∈𝒦for-all𝑘superscript𝑘′𝒦\forall k,k^{\prime}\in\mathcal{K}, k≠k′𝑘superscript𝑘′k\neq k^{\prime}, the representation 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} is client-invariant. We illustrate the sufficient conditions for the client-invariant representation extraction with the conditional mutual information term I​(𝒛;k|y)𝐼𝒛conditional𝑘𝑦I(\bm{z};k|y) in the following proposition.

Proposition 2.

Given a label class y𝑦y, a representation 𝐳𝐳\bm{z} is client-invariant if and only if I​(𝐳;k|y)=0𝐼𝐳conditional𝑘𝑦0I(\bm{z};k|y)=0, where I​(𝐳;k|y)𝐼𝐳conditional𝑘𝑦I(\bm{z};k|y) is the conditional mutual information between 𝐳𝐳\bm{z} and k𝑘k.

Proof.

See Appendix C. ∎

According to Proposition 2, the representation Z𝑍Z is client-invariant when I​(Z;K|Y)=0𝐼𝑍conditional𝐾𝑌0I(Z;K|Y)=0 given the label Y𝑌Y. Therefore, to achieve client-invariant representation learning, we need to reduce the conditional mutual information I​(Z;K|Y)=∑k∈𝒦∫Y∫Zp​(k,y)​p​(𝒛|k,y)​log⁡p​(𝒛|k,y)p​(𝒛|y)​d​𝒛​d​y𝐼𝑍conditional𝐾𝑌subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦𝑑𝒛𝑑𝑦I(Z;K|Y)=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(k,y)p(\bm{z}|k,y)\log\frac{p(\bm{z}|k,y)}{p(\bm{z}|y)}d\bm{z}dy in FL. However, this term is hard to compute in FL since it requires the conditional distribution p​(𝒛|k,y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦p(\bm{z}|k,y) and the global representation distribution p​(𝒛|y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦p(\bm{z}|y). To tackle this issue, we derive an upper bound for the conditional mutual information I​(Z;K|Y)𝐼𝑍conditional𝐾𝑌I(Z;K|Y) with the approximate global representation distribution q​(𝒛|y)𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦q(\bm{z}|y) in the following proposition.

Proposition 3.

Let q​(𝐳|y)𝑞conditional𝐳𝑦q(\bm{z}|y) be the approximation of the global representation distribution p​(𝐳|y)𝑝conditional𝐳𝑦p(\bm{z}|y). The conditional mutual information I​(Z;K|Y)𝐼𝑍conditional𝐾𝑌I(Z;K|Y) can be bounded as follows:

I​(Z;K|Y)≤ℒa​l​i​g​n,𝐼𝑍conditional𝐾𝑌subscriptℒ𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\begin{split}&I(Z;K|Y)\leq\mathcal{L}_{align},\end{split} (13)

where

ℒa​l​i​g​n=∑k∈𝒦p(k)𝔼p​(𝒙,y|k)DKL(p(𝒛|k,𝒙)∥q(𝒛|y)),\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{align}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\mathbb{E}_{p(\bm{x},y|k)}D_{\text{KL}}\big{(}p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x})\|q(\bm{z}|y)\big{)}, (14)

and DKL(p(𝐳|k,𝐱)∥q(𝐳|y))=p(𝐳|k,𝐱)logp​(𝐳|k,𝐱)q​(𝐳|y)D_{\text{KL}}\big{(}p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x})\|q(\bm{z}|y)\big{)}=p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x})\log\frac{p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x})}{q(\bm{z}|y)} is the Kullback–Leible (KL) divergence between the local and approximate global representation distributions.

Proof.

See Appendix D. ∎

Similar to ℒr​e​gsubscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔\mathcal{L}_{reg}, the upper bound ℒa​l​i​g​nsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\mathcal{L}_{align} in Proposition 3 can be used as a regularizer in FL for client-invariant feature extraction. By using ℒa​l​i​g​nsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\mathcal{L}_{align} as the proxy of I​(Z;K|Y)𝐼𝑍conditional𝐾𝑌I(Z;K|Y), we can reduce I​(Z;K|Y)𝐼𝑍conditional𝐾𝑌I(Z;K|Y) by minimizing ℒa​l​i​g​nsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\mathcal{L}_{align}, thereby achieving client-invariant feature extraction. To be specific, each client downloads the approximate global representation distribution q​(𝒛|y)𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦q(\bm{z}|y) from the server, and aligns the local representation distribution p​(𝒛|k,𝒙)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝒙p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x}) with q​(𝒛|y)𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦q(\bm{z}|y) for the same class y𝑦y using the KL divergence in local training. The representation distribution alignment helps to reduce the divergence between global and local representation distributions, thus encouraging clients to share the same representation distribution, i.e., p​(𝒛|k,𝒙,y)≈p​(𝒛|k′,𝒙,y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝒙𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛superscript𝑘′𝒙𝑦p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x},y)\approx p(\bm{z}|k^{\prime},\bm{x},y), k,k′∈𝒦𝑘superscript𝑘′𝒦k,k^{\prime}\in\mathcal{K}.

5.3 Global Representation Distribution Approximation

We note that the derived upper bounds of two mutual information terms, i.e., ℒr​e​gsubscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔\mathcal{L}_{reg} and ℒa​l​i​g​nsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\mathcal{L}_{align}, rely on the approximation of the global representation distribution p​(𝒛|y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦p(\bm{z}|y), i.e., q​(𝒛|y)𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦q(\bm{z}|y). Nonetheless, the distributed local samples in clients make it difficult to approximate the global representation distribution p​(𝒛|y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦p(\bm{z}|y) in FL. To tackle this issue, we propose to approximate the global representation distribution with a generative network for clients using a data-free mechanism. In particular, we use a generator G𝐺G parameterized by 𝒘gsubscript𝒘𝑔\bm{w}_{g} to generate the representation distribution q𝒘g​(𝒛|y)subscript𝑞subscript𝒘𝑔conditional𝒛𝑦q_{\bm{w}_{g}}(\bm{z}|y) (we also omit 𝒘gsubscript𝒘𝑔\bm{w}_{g} for notation simplicity), which is then optimized at the server in each communication round. Since the global model obtained by aggregating local models loses the local knowledge, we exploit the ensemble predictions of the local models to optimize the generator G𝐺G by minimizing the following objective function:

ℒg=𝔼p​(y)​𝔼q​(𝒛|y)​[−log​∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​p^​(y|k,𝒛)],subscriptℒ𝑔subscript𝔼𝑝𝑦subscript𝔼𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{g}=\mathbb{E}_{p(y)}\mathbb{E}_{q(\bm{z}|y)}\left[-\log\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\hat{p}({y}|k,\bm{z})\right], (15)

where q​(𝒛|y)≡G​(y,ϵ|ϵ∼𝒩​(0,𝑰))𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦𝐺similar-to𝑦conditionalbold-italic-ϵbold-italic-ϵ𝒩0𝑰q(\bm{z}|y)\equiv G(y,\bm{\epsilon}|\bm{\epsilon}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\bm{I})) is the generated representation distribution, and p^​(y|k,𝒛)^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛\hat{p}({y}|k,\bm{z}) is the predicted logit output by the local model from client k𝑘k. FedGen [13] requires additional training data distribution for representation distribution approximation, which is vulnerable to gradient inversion attacks [33] and brings extensive privacy risks. Instead, our proposed data-free mechanism only leverages the local models to approximate the global representation distribution and does not bring extra privacy exposure. For any given class label y𝑦y, by maximizing the agreement of local models, the representation 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} generated by the generator network achieves the maximum consensus of them, thereby effectively approximating the global distribution representation.

5.4 Training Details and Overall Framework of FedCiR

By integrating ℒf​lsubscriptℒ𝑓𝑙\mathcal{L}_{fl} and the proposed two regularization terms ℒr​e​qsubscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑞\mathcal{L}_{req} and ℒa​l​i​g​nsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\mathcal{L}_{align} obtained by the Proposition 1 and Proposition 3, respectively, the global objective function of the proposed method FedCiR is given by:

ℒF​e​d​C​i​R=ℒf​l+λr​e​g​ℒr​e​g+λa​l​i​g​n​ℒa​l​i​g​n,subscriptℒ𝐹𝑒𝑑𝐶𝑖𝑅subscriptℒ𝑓𝑙subscript𝜆𝑟𝑒𝑔subscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔subscript𝜆𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛subscriptℒ𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{FedCiR}=\mathcal{L}_{fl}+\lambda_{reg}\mathcal{L}_{reg}+\lambda_{align}\mathcal{L}_{align}, (16)

where λr​e​gsubscript𝜆𝑟𝑒𝑔\lambda_{reg} and λr​e​gsubscript𝜆𝑟𝑒𝑔\lambda_{reg} are the hyperparameters for the regularization terms. With these two regularizers, FedCiR can achieve label-discriminative and client-invariant feature extraction and solve the feature shift issue in FL. In the following, we elaborate on the training details of FedCiR.

KL divergence between local and approximate global representation distributions DKL(p(𝒛|k,𝒙)∥q(𝒛|y))D_{\text{KL}}\big{(}p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x})\|q(\bm{z}|y)\big{)}: To compute DKL(p(𝒛|k,𝒙)∥q(𝒛|y))D_{\text{KL}}\big{(}p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x})\|q(\bm{z}|y)\big{)} in (14), following [46], we assume that the global representation distribution q​(𝒛|y)𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦q(\bm{z}|y) is a Gaussian distribution, which can be parameterized by the mean 𝝁g​(y)subscript𝝁𝑔𝑦\bm{\mu}_{g}(y) and standard deviation 𝝈g​(y)subscript𝝈𝑔𝑦\bm{\sigma}_{g}(y) for each class y𝑦y. Note that the generator G𝐺G outputs the representations samples instead of the distribution q​(𝒛|y)𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦q(\bm{z}|y). Hence, we estimate the mean 𝝁g​(y)subscript𝝁𝑔𝑦\bm{\mu}_{g}(y) and standard deviation 𝝈g​(y)subscript𝝈𝑔𝑦\bm{\sigma}_{g}(y) for each class y𝑦y at the server using the maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) method. As such, the KL divergence [47] between p​(𝒛|k,𝒙)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝒙p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x}) and q​(𝒛|y)𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦q(\bm{z}|y) in (14) can be computed as follows:

DKL(p(𝒛|k,𝒙)∥q(𝒛|y))=log𝝈g(y)−log𝝈𝒘1(y)\displaystyle D_{\text{KL}}(p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x})\|q(\bm{z}|y))=\log\bm{\sigma}_{g}(y)-\log\bm{\sigma}_{\bm{w}_{1}}(y)
+𝝈𝒘12​(𝒙)+(𝝁𝒘1​(𝒙)−𝝁g​(y))22​𝝈g2​(y)−12.superscriptsubscript𝝈subscript𝒘12𝒙superscriptsubscript𝝁subscript𝒘1𝒙subscript𝝁𝑔𝑦22superscriptsubscript𝝈𝑔2𝑦12\displaystyle\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad+\frac{\bm{\sigma}_{\bm{w}_{1}}^{2}(\bm{x})+(\bm{\mu}_{\bm{w}_{1}}(\bm{x})-\bm{\mu}_{g}(y))^{2}}{2\bm{\sigma}_{g}^{2}(y)}-\frac{1}{2}. (17)

The training process of the FedCiR framework, which is illustrated in Figure 2 and summarized in Algorithm 1, involves iterative steps where clients carry out local training, and the server performs global aggregation and global representation distribution approximation. The details of these two steps are provided as follows.

Local training: In each communication round t=1,⋯,𝒯𝑡1⋯𝒯t=1,\cdots,\mathcal{T}, a subset of clients 𝒦tsubscript𝒦𝑡\mathcal{K}_{t} from 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} is active, and they download the global model and global representation distribution set {𝝁g​(y),𝝈g​(y)}y=0C−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑔𝑦subscript𝝈𝑔𝑦𝑦0𝐶1\{\bm{\mu}_{g}(y),\bm{\sigma}_{g}(y)\}_{y=0}^{C-1} from the server. At each step e∈[E]𝑒delimited-[]𝐸e\in[E] of the t𝑡t-th local training, the active client k𝑘k samples a mini-batch of data ξkt,e={𝒙i,yi}i=1Bsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑡𝑒superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝐵\xi_{k}^{t,e}=\{\bm{x}_{i},y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{B} with B𝐵B samples and input them into the encoder 𝒘1subscript𝒘1\bm{w}_{1} to obtain the representation distribution p​(𝒛|𝒙i)𝑝conditional𝒛subscript𝒙𝑖p(\bm{z}|\bm{x}_{i}) parameterized by 𝝁𝒘1​(𝒙i)subscript𝝁subscript𝒘1subscript𝒙𝑖\bm{\mu}_{\bm{w}_{1}}(\bm{x}_{i}) and 𝝈𝒘1​(𝒙i)subscript𝝈subscript𝒘1subscript𝒙𝑖\bm{\sigma}_{\bm{w}_{1}}(\bm{x}_{i}) for each data sample 𝒙isubscript𝒙𝑖\bm{x}_{i}. These representation distributions are used to compute the KL divergence term in (17). Besides, we sample a representation 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} from the distribution p​(𝒛|k,𝒙i)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘subscript𝒙𝑖p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x}_{i}), which is then input into the classifier to compute the loss term ℒf​lsubscriptℒ𝑓𝑙\mathcal{L}_{fl}. To compute ℒr​e​gsubscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔\mathcal{L}_{reg} in (12), we sample a mini-batch size B𝐵B of Gaussian noise vectors {ϵi|ϵi∼𝒩​(0,𝑰)}i=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptconditional-setsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖similar-tosubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝒩0𝑰𝑖1𝐵\{\bm{\epsilon}_{i}|\bm{\epsilon}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\bm{I})\}_{i=1}^{B} and label instances {yi}i=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝐵\{y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{B} over a uniform distribution. The samples are input into the generator for generating the global representations, which are then input into the classifier for regularizing the local classifier. Following the classical FedAvg method described in Section 3, the local objective function with the mini-batch of samples ξkt,esuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑡𝑒\xi_{k}^{t,e} for client k𝑘k is given by:

ℒk​(𝒘)=subscriptℒ𝑘𝒘absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{k}(\bm{w})= 𝔼(𝒙i,yi)∈ξkt,e[−log𝔼p​(𝒛|𝒙i)p^(y|k,𝒛)\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{(\bm{x}_{i},y_{i})\in\xi_{k}^{t,e}}[-\log\mathbb{E}_{p(\bm{z}|{\bm{x}_{i}})}\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z})
+λr​e​g​𝔼p​(y)​𝔼q​(𝒛|y)​[−log⁡p^​(y|k,𝒛)]subscript𝜆𝑟𝑒𝑔subscript𝔼𝑝𝑦subscript𝔼𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦delimited-[]^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛\displaystyle+\lambda_{reg}\mathbb{E}_{p(y)}\mathbb{E}_{q(\bm{z}|y)}[-\log\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z})]
+λa​l​i​g​nDKL(p(𝒛|k,𝒙i)∥q(𝒛|yi))].\displaystyle+\lambda_{align}D_{\text{KL}}(p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x}_{i})\|q(\bm{z}|y_{i}))]. (18)

Gloabl aggregation and global representation distribution approximation: After local training, the clients share the local models with the server as in FedAvg. Besides the global model aggregation, the server optimizes the generator 𝒘gsubscript𝒘𝑔\bm{w}_{g} with the help of local classifiers for Egsubscript𝐸𝑔E_{g} steps. Specifically, at each step e∈[Eg]𝑒delimited-[]subscript𝐸𝑔e\in[E_{g}] of the generator updating, the server samples a mini-batch size B𝐵B of Gaussian noise vectors {ϵi|ϵi∼𝒩​(0,𝑰)}i=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptconditional-setsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖similar-tosubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝒩0𝑰𝑖1𝐵\{\bm{\epsilon}_{i}|\bm{\epsilon}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\bm{I})\}_{i=1}^{B} and label instances {yi}i=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝐵\{y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{B} over a uniform distribution. The server obtains the representations by inputting the Gaussian noise vectors and label instances into the generator 𝒘gsubscript𝒘𝑔\bm{w}_{g}. To encourage the generator to maximize the agreement of all the clients, the server inputs the representations into all the uploaded local classifiers to compute the ensemble predictions. Then, the generator is optimized by minimizing the cross-entropy loss between the ensemble predictions and the corresponding labels. To relieve the computation burden for clients, the server updates the global representation distribution set {𝝁g​(y),𝝈g​(y)}y=0C−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑔𝑦subscript𝝈𝑔𝑦𝑦0𝐶1\{\bm{\mu}_{g}(y),\bm{\sigma}_{g}(y)\}_{y=0}^{C-1} for each class via MLE, which will be downloaded by the clients along with the global model in the next round.

6 Experiments

In this section, we evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed FedCiR framework in solving the feature shift problem in FL. We first summarize the experiment setup in Section 6.1, and compare FedCiR with several state-of-the-art (SOTA) FL algorithms on benchmark and real-world datasets in Section 6.2. In Section 6.3, ablation studies are conducted to demonstrate the sensitivity of FedCiR on hyperparameters. To illustrate the effectiveness of FedCiR in client-invariant representation training as discussed in Theorem 2, we further compare FedCiR with FedAvg in terms of local risks and ℋℋ\mathcal{H}-divergence in Section 6.4. An overhead analysis is conducted in Section 6.5 to demonstrate that FedCiR is energy-friendly in terms of computation, communication, and GPU memory.

6.1 Experiment Setup

Baselines: Apart from FedAvg [1], we compare FedCiR against several SOTA FL algorithms in solving the non-IID issue, including FedProx [25], FedProc [17], FedGen [13], and FedSR [44]. To gain more insights from FedCiR, we develop two more baselines: FedReg and FedAlign. Specifically, FedReg only improves the global knowledge for local models with the regularizer ℒr​e​gsubscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔\mathcal{L}_{reg}, while FedAlign only utilizes the regularizer ℒa​l​i​g​nsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\mathcal{L}_{align} to force the representations to be client-invariant.

Datasets: We consider both benchmark and real-world datasets, including DomainNet [43], PACS [48], Office-Caltech-10 [49], Camelyon17 [50], and Iwildcam [51], which contain multiple domains of data, e.g., photos, art paintings, cartoon images, and sketch images on PACS. For FL, We consider the feature shift scenarios where each client has only one domain of data that are resized to 128×128128128128\times 128 pixels. The Camelyon17 dataset is a binary classification task for detecting tumors in varying hospitals and the Iwildcam dataset is a multi-class classification task for wildlife animal images captured by cameras at different locations. For the Iwildcam dataset, the data among cameras (clients) are both label-skewed and feature-skewed, and most of them are invalid background data and useless for training. Therefore, we only use ten classes of samples in ten of the cameras that have the largest data volume.

Moreover, apart from the feature-skewed data distribution, we also evaluate the effectiveness of FedCiR on label-skewed data distribution, where the data in each domain are distributed to multiple clients (number of clients / number of domains) according to the Latent Dirichlet Sampling with varying Dirichlet parameters β𝛽\beta.

Model structures: We use ResNet18 [52] as the backbone for all the datasets. For FedCiR and FedGen, the generator is composed of two fully connected layers with ReLU and BatchNorm layers between them.

Hyperparameters: In the main experiments, we set the local updating steps E=20𝐸20E=20 and communication rounds T=300𝑇300T=300. During local training, we use SGD with batch size 32, learning rate 0.010.010.01, momentum 0.9, and weight decay 5×10−45superscript1045\times 10^{-4}, as the local optimizer. For FedCiR and FedGen, the server optimizes the generator for 5 steps (Eg=5)subscript𝐸𝑔5(E_{g}=5) in each communication round. More details of hyperparameters for FedCiR and baselines are available in Appendix E.

6.2 Performance Evaluation

Test accuracy: Table I presents the test accuracy of FedCiR and the baselines, where the first row shows the performance of centralized training. As shown in Table I, FedCiR outperforms the baselines on all the datasets, surpassing FedGen by 1.24%percent1.241.24\% and 1.8%percent1.81.8\% on DomainNet and PACS, respectively. FedGen employs a data-free knowledge distillation mechanism to regularize the local models, resulting in a better performance compared with FedAvg and FedProx. FedProc and FedSR rely on the feature alignment to minimize the local model divergence. However, the experiment results reveal that they exhibit instability with different random seeds on some datasets, e.g., DomainNet and PACS. This is because the average prototypes and representation networks in the server cannot accurately identify the precise features for alignment in the feature space as compared with our proposed data-free mechanism for representation distribution approximation. In addition, FedCiR is consistently superior to the baselines on the real-world datasets: Camelyon17 and Iwildcam, which demonstrates its effectiveness in practical applications.

Convergence rate: Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 illustrate the convergence rate of FedCiR and baselines on DomainNet and PACS, respectively. FedCiR achieves a significantly faster convergence rate compared with the baselines. While FedGen may enjoy a higher learning efficiency in some settings by relying on effective proxy data, our proposed approach can explicitly align the representation distributions of all the clients and extract client-invariant representations, thereby achieving the fastest convergence rate.

Data heterogeneity: In addition to the feature-skewed scenarios, we further evaluate the performance of all the methods in various label-skewed settings on DomainNet and PACS datasets. As shown in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6, FedCiR outperforms the baselines in all the scenarios, which demonstrates that our proposed method can handle all kinds of non-IID scenarios, including those with feature-skewed and label-skewed data distributions. As the non-IID degree decreases, i.e., as β𝛽\beta increases, the test accuracy of all the methods improves as expected. Moreover, FedCiR obtains competitive results under highly-skewed scenarios, e.g., it achieves nearly 5%percent55\% higher accuracy than the second-best method on PACS when β=0.5𝛽0.5\beta=0.5.

6.3 Sensitivity Analysis

Impact of client number and active ratio: We investigate the impact of client number and active ratio for FedCiR and the baselines. Fig 7 and Fig. 8 illustrate that, under different total client and active client numbers, FedCiR achieves the best performance in all the settings. For example, FedCiR outperforms the second-best algorithm by 3.5%percent\% on PACS when the total client number is 50 and the active client number is 10. Notably, the accuracy of FedProc and FedSR is sensitive to the numbers of clients due to the unstable prototypes and representation networks averaged over them. In contrast, FedCiR maintains stable and competitive performance across all the settings, highlighting the effectiveness and stability of client-invariant representation learning.

Impact of local steps: We study the effect of the number of local updating steps on the accuracy of all the methods on DomainNet and PACS datasets. As depicted in Fig. 9 and Fig. 10, appropriate large values of local updating steps promote the accuracy performance for all the methods. Furthermore, FedCiR is robust against all the baselines at different levels of local updating steps, particularly on the PACS dataset. Notably, when the number of local steps exceeds 100, FedCiR outperforms the second-best baseline by more than 3%percent\%, indicating its high training reliability and efficiency.

Robustness of hyperparameters: To evaluate the influence of hyperparameter selection, we conduct experiments with different hyperparameters in FedCiR on PACS. Results in Table II show that FedCiR is insensitive to the hyperparameters λr​e​gsubscript𝜆𝑟𝑒𝑔\lambda_{reg}, achieving an accuracy of about 68%percent6868\% with λr​e​g∈[0.1,1.0]subscript𝜆𝑟𝑒𝑔0.11.0\lambda_{reg}\in[0.1,1.0] and λa​l​i​g​n=5×10−6subscript𝜆𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛5superscript106\lambda_{align}=5\times 10^{-6}. Without the proposed regularization term ℒr​e​gsubscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔\mathcal{L}_{reg}, i.e., λr​e​g=0.0subscript𝜆𝑟𝑒𝑔0.0\lambda_{reg}=0.0, FedCiR only achieves 63.53%percent\% accuracy, highlighting the effectiveness of our proposed term for knowledge augmentation. We also find that selecting an appropriate large value for λa​l​i​g​nsubscript𝜆𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\lambda_{align}, e.g., λa​l​i​g​n>1×10−6subscript𝜆𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛1superscript106\lambda_{align}>1\times 10^{-6}, yields better performance for FedCiR, whereas using an extremely small value of λa​l​i​g​nsubscript𝜆𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\lambda_{align} cannot extract sufficient client-invariant features for classification, resulting an accuracy of only 63.83%percent63.8363.83\% when λa​l​i​g​n=0subscript𝜆𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛0\lambda_{align}=0.

6.4 Insight Analysis

To verify the effectiveness of FedCiR in client-invariant representation learning as discussed in Theorem 2, we empirically calculate the reduction of local risks and ℋℋ\mathcal{H}-divergence between local and global datasets compared with FedAvg on DomainNet. Similar to [19, 34], we approximate the ℋℋ\mathcal{H}-divergence by discriminating a pair of datasets using a classifier. Specifically, we label two datasets 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and 𝒟jsubscript𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}_{j} as 0 and 1, respectively, and train a classifier, e.g., a linear SVM, to distinguish between them and calculate the test error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. The proxy A-distance (PAD) between 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and 𝒟jsubscript𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}_{j}, defined as 2​(1−2​ϵ)212italic-ϵ2(1-2\epsilon), is used to approximate the ℋℋ\mathcal{H}-divergence.

Fig. 11 presents the comparison of the average local risks of clients on DomainNet for FedCiR and FedAvg. The results show that FedCiR consistently outperforms FedAvg in terms of lower risks in clients. This is because the client-invariant representations induced by FedCiR reduce the discrepancy among local models. Consequently, the aggregated global model becomes more generalized for local datasets, resulting in lower local errors. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 12, the average PAD between global and local datasets is smaller in FedCiR than in FedAvg (i.e., the dot is below the diagonal), which verifies the effectiveness of FedCiR in reducing the ℋℋ\mathcal{H}-divergence between global and local datasets. Moreover, the PAD between any pairs of local datasets is also lower in FedCiR than in FedAvg, explicitly demonstrating that FedCiR can extract more client-invariant representations compared with FedAvg.

6.5 Overhead Analysis

Finally, we evaluate the overhead regarding computational and communication costs for each client as well as GPU memories to reach 60%percent6060\% accuracy for different methods on DomainNet. The results are presented in Table III.

Computational costs: Our proposed FedCiR spends less computational costs to reach 60%percent6060\% accuracy against baselines. Although FedCiR includes the feature generator and global representation distributions for local regularization, which increases the computational costs in each training round, the faster convergence rate significantly reduces the training rounds for FedCiR to reach 60%percent6060\% accuracy, thus relieving the total computational costs for clients.

Communication costs: FedSR achieves the best performance and FedCiR realizes the second-best performance in communication cost saving. This is because both of them achieve remarkably faster convergence rates compared with other methods, and additionally downloading the feature generator from the server takes FedCiR more communication costs than FedSR at clients.

GPU memory: Serving as a basic framework for FL, FedAvg occupies the least GPU memories for computation. The other methods require more GPU memories for computation due to the extra components for local regularization, e.g., the global representations in FedProc and FedSR. FedGen and FedCiR occupy the most GPU memories for computation, e.g., with 0.14GB more than FedAvg. This is because they utilize a feature generator for regulating the local update and thus demand more GPU memories. Even so, compared with the 7.717.717.71GB GPU memories for FedAvg, the additional GPU memories (i.e., 0.14GB) for local regularization in FedCiR are small and negligible.

To sum up, our proposed FedCiR is able to save computational and communication costs compared with most of the baselines, which is attributed to the fast convergence rate. Moreover, the additional regularizers for solving the feature shift problem only increase negligible GPU memories over the baselines.

7 Conclusions

In this paper, we proposed a novel federated representation learning framework, called FedCiR, to solve the feature-skewed issue in FL. Based on our established generalization error bound for FL, we proposed to extract informative and client-invariant features by utilizing two mutual information terms. FedCiR incorporated two regularization terms to bound these two mutual information terms with the global representation distribution, which not only improves global knowledge but also facilitates client-invariant representation training. To mitigate the issue of the absence of global representation distribution in FL, we employed a generator to approximate it through a data-free mechanism. Experiments verified the effectiveness of FedCiR in client-invariant representation extraction and solving the data heterogeneity issue. In the future, we will investigate how to utilize pretrained generative models to solve the federated feature shift problem by generating the insufficient domains of data for devices.

Appendix A Proof of Theorem 2

Consider the FL framework that collaboratively trains a global hypothesis 𝒉^^𝒉\hat{\bm{h}} to classify representations with |𝒦|𝒦|\mathcal{K}| distributed source domains {⟨ℛk,𝒓k⟩}k∈𝒦subscriptsubscriptℛ𝑘subscript𝒓𝑘𝑘𝒦\{\langle\mathcal{R}_{k},\bm{r}_{k}\rangle\}_{k\in\mathcal{K}}. Since the global hypothesis is computed by a weighted sum for all the local hypotheses trained on local source domains, the generalization error bound can be computed as follows:

ε​(𝒉^)≡ε​(∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​𝒉^k).𝜀^𝒉𝜀subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript^𝒉𝑘\varepsilon(\hat{\bm{h}})\equiv\varepsilon\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\hat{\bm{h}}_{k}\right). (19)

We use a one-layer fully-connected layer followed by a softmax layer as the hypothesis 𝒉^^𝒉\hat{\bm{h}} and the cross-entropy function to compute the risk ε​(𝒉^)𝜀^𝒉\varepsilon(\hat{\bm{h}}), which is convex for any source data. Combining with Theorem 1, we can bound (19) as below:

ε​(𝒉^)≡𝜀^𝒉absent\displaystyle\varepsilon(\hat{\bm{h}})\equiv ε​(∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​𝒉^k)≤∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​ε​(𝒉^k)𝜀subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript^𝒉𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘𝜀subscript^𝒉𝑘\displaystyle\varepsilon\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\hat{\bm{h}}_{k}\right)\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\varepsilon(\hat{\bm{h}}_{k}) (20)
≤\displaystyle\leq ∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​εk​(𝒉^k)+∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​d𝒢^​(ℛk,ℛ~)subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝜀𝑘subscript^𝒉𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝑑^𝒢subscriptℛ𝑘~ℛ\displaystyle\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\varepsilon_{{k}}(\hat{\bm{h}}_{k})+\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)d_{\hat{\mathcal{G}}}(\mathcal{R}_{k},\tilde{\mathcal{R}})
+∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​min⁡{𝔼𝒟k​[|𝒓k−𝒓~|],𝔼𝒟T​[|𝒓k−𝒓~|]},subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝔼subscript𝒟𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝒓𝑘~𝒓subscript𝔼subscript𝒟𝑇delimited-[]subscript𝒓𝑘~𝒓\displaystyle+\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\min\{\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}_{k}}[|\bm{r}_{k}-\tilde{\bm{r}}|],\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}_{T}}[|\bm{r}_{k}-\tilde{\bm{r}}|]\}, (21)

where 𝒢^^𝒢\hat{\mathcal{G}} is the conditional function class for the hypotheses 𝒈^^𝒈\hat{\bm{g}} that 𝒈^​(𝒛)≔sign​(|𝒉^​(𝒛)−𝒉^′​(𝒛)|−m)≔^𝒈𝒛sign^𝒉𝒛superscript^𝒉′𝒛𝑚\hat{\bm{g}}(\bm{z})\coloneqq\text{sign}(|\hat{\bm{h}}(\bm{z})-\hat{\bm{h}}^{\prime}(\bm{z})|-m) with 𝒉^,𝒉^′∈ℋ^^𝒉superscript^𝒉′^ℋ{\hat{\bm{h}}},{\hat{\bm{h}}}^{\prime}\in{\hat{\mathcal{H}}} and 0≤m≤10𝑚10\leq m\leq 1, and ℛksubscriptℛ𝑘\mathcal{R}_{k} and ℛ~~ℛ\tilde{\mathcal{R}} are the induced representation distributions of 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} and 𝒟~~𝒟\tilde{\mathcal{D}}, respectively.

Under the covariate shift assumption that 𝒓~=𝒓k~𝒓subscript𝒓𝑘\tilde{\bm{r}}=\bm{r}_{k}, the third term in (21) equals 0. Hence, we obtain

ε​(𝒉^)≤∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​εk​(𝒉^k)+∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​d𝒢^​(ℛk,ℛ~).𝜀^𝒉subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝜀𝑘subscript^𝒉𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝑑^𝒢subscriptℛ𝑘~ℛ\displaystyle\varepsilon(\hat{\bm{h}})\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\varepsilon_{{k}}(\hat{\bm{h}}_{k})+\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)d_{\hat{\mathcal{G}}}(\mathcal{R}_{k},\tilde{\mathcal{R}}). (22)

Appendix B Proof of Proposition 1

By extending the mutual information term between labels and representations, we have

−I​(Y;Z)𝐼𝑌𝑍\displaystyle-I(Y;Z) =−∫Y∫Zp​(y,𝒛)​log​p​(y,𝒛)p​(y)​p​(𝒛)​𝑑𝒛​𝑑yabsentsubscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑦𝒛log𝑝𝑦𝒛𝑝𝑦𝑝𝒛differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦\displaystyle=-\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(y,\bm{z})\text{log}\frac{p(y,\bm{z})}{p(y)p(\bm{z})}d\bm{z}dy (23)
=−∫Y∫Zp​(y,𝒛)​log​p​(y|𝒛)​𝑑𝒛​𝑑y+H​(Y).absentsubscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑦𝒛log𝑝conditional𝑦𝒛differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦𝐻𝑌\displaystyle=-\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(y,\bm{z})\text{log}p(y|\bm{z})d\bm{z}dy+H(Y). (24)

Notice that the entropy of labels H​(Y)𝐻𝑌H(Y) is independent of model optimization. Thus, H​(Y)𝐻𝑌H(Y) can be ignored in (24) and we have

−I​(Y;Z)𝐼𝑌𝑍\displaystyle-I(Y;Z) ≡∫Y∫Zp​(y,𝒛)​[−log​p​(y|𝒛)]​𝑑𝒛​𝑑yabsentsubscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑦𝒛delimited-[]log𝑝conditional𝑦𝒛differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦\displaystyle\equiv\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(y,\bm{z})[-\text{log}p(y|\bm{z})]d\bm{z}dy (25)
=∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​∫Y∫Zp​(y,𝒛)​[−log​p​(y|𝒛)]​𝑑𝒛​𝑑y.absentsubscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑦𝒛delimited-[]log𝑝conditional𝑦𝒛differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦\displaystyle=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(y,\bm{z})[-\text{log}{p}(y|\bm{z})]d\bm{z}dy. (26)

Since the conditional distribution p​(y|𝒛)𝑝conditional𝑦𝒛p(y|\bm{z}) is intractable in FL, we use the local predition distribution p^​(y|k,𝒛)^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z}) as a variational approximation to p​(y|𝒛)𝑝conditional𝑦𝒛p(y|\bm{z}). According to the fact that the KL divergence is always positive, we have

DKL(p(Y|Z)||p^(Y|K,Z))≥0\displaystyle D_{\text{KL}}(p(Y|Z)||\hat{p}(Y|K,Z))\geq 0 (27)
⇒⇒\displaystyle\Rightarrow ∫Y∫Zp​(y,𝒛)​log​p​(𝒛|y)p^​(𝒛|k,y)​𝑑𝒛​𝑑y≥0.subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑦𝒛log𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦^𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦0\displaystyle\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(y,\bm{z})\text{log}\frac{p(\bm{z}|y)}{\hat{p}(\bm{z}|k,y)}d\bm{z}dy\geq 0. (28)

As the clients download the global model for local training every communication round, it is reasonable to use p^​(y|k,𝒛)^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z}) to approximate p​(y|𝒛)𝑝conditional𝑦𝒛p(y|\bm{z}), and the distribution gap between them is significantly tight when the local steps are small. Hence, we have

−I​(Y;Z)𝐼𝑌𝑍\displaystyle\quad-I(Y;Z)
≤∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​∫Y∫Zp​(y,𝒛)​[−log​p^​(y|k,𝒛)]​𝑑𝒛​𝑑yabsentsubscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑦𝒛delimited-[]log^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(y,\bm{z})[-\text{log}\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z})]d\bm{z}dy (29)
≤∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​∫Yp​(y)​∫Zp​(𝒛|y)​[−log​p^​(y|k,𝒛)]​𝑑𝒛​𝑑y.absentsubscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝑌𝑝𝑦subscript𝑍𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦delimited-[]log^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\int_{Y}p(y)\int_{Z}p(\bm{z}|y)[-\text{log}\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z})]d\bm{z}dy. (30)

By using q​(𝒛|y)𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦q(\bm{z}|y) to approximate the global representation distribution p​(𝒛|y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦p(\bm{z}|y), we have

−I​(Y;Z)𝐼𝑌𝑍\displaystyle\quad-I(Y;Z)
≤∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​∫Yp​(y)​∫Zp​(𝒛|y)​[−log​p^​(y|k,𝒛)]​𝑑𝒛​𝑑yabsentsubscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝑌𝑝𝑦subscript𝑍𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦delimited-[]log^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\int_{Y}p(y)\int_{Z}p(\bm{z}|y)[-\text{log}\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z})]d\bm{z}dy (31)
≈∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​∫Yp​(y)​∫Zq​(𝒛|y)​[−log​p^​(y|k,𝒛)]​𝑑𝒛​𝑑yabsentsubscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝑌𝑝𝑦subscript𝑍𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦delimited-[]log^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦\displaystyle\approx\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\int_{Y}p(y)\int_{Z}q(\bm{z}|y)[-\text{log}\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z})]d\bm{z}dy (32)
≤∑k∈𝒦p​(k)​𝔼p​(y)​𝔼q​(𝒛|y)​[−log⁡p^​(y|k,𝒛)]=ℒr​e​g.absentsubscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘subscript𝔼𝑝𝑦subscript𝔼𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦delimited-[]^𝑝conditional𝑦𝑘𝒛subscriptℒ𝑟𝑒𝑔\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\mathbb{E}_{p(y)}\mathbb{E}_{q(\bm{z}|y)}[-\log\hat{p}(y|k,\bm{z})]=\mathcal{L}_{reg}. (33)

Appendix C Proof of Proposition 2

To prove that given a label class y𝑦y, a representation 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} is client-invariant if and only if I​(𝒛;k|y)=0𝐼𝒛conditional𝑘𝑦0I(\bm{z};k|y)=0, we establish the following separate proofs:

  • •

    Given a class y𝑦y, if I​(𝒛;k|y)=0𝐼𝒛conditional𝑘𝑦0I(\bm{z};k|y)=0, then p​(𝒛|y)=p​(𝒛|k,y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦p(\bm{z}|y)=p(\bm{z}|k,y), so that p​(𝒛|k,y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦p(\bm{z}|k,y) is invariant w.r.t. k𝑘k.

  • •

    Given a class y𝑦y, if p​(𝒛|k,y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦p(\bm{z}|k,y) is invariant w.r.t. k𝑘k, then ∀𝒛,k::for-all𝒛𝑘absent\forall\bm{z},k:

    p​(𝒛|y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦\displaystyle p(\bm{z}|y) =∑k∈𝒦p​(𝒛|k,y)​p​(k|y)absentsubscript𝑘𝒦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝑘𝑦\displaystyle=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(\bm{z}|k,y)p(k|y) (34)
    =∑k∈𝒦p​(𝒛|k′,y)​p​(k|y)absentsubscript𝑘𝒦𝑝conditional𝒛superscript𝑘′𝑦𝑝conditional𝑘𝑦\displaystyle=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(\bm{z}|k^{\prime},y)p(k|y) (35)
    =p​(𝒛|k′,y)​∑k∈𝒦p​(k|y)absent𝑝conditional𝒛superscript𝑘′𝑦subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝conditional𝑘𝑦\displaystyle=p(\bm{z}|k^{\prime},y)\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k|y) (36)
    =p​(𝒛|k′,y)​∑k∈𝒦p​(k,y)p​(y)absent𝑝conditional𝒛superscript𝑘′𝑦subscript𝑘𝒦𝑝𝑘𝑦𝑝𝑦\displaystyle=p(\bm{z}|k^{\prime},y)\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{p(k,y)}{p(y)} (37)
    =p​(𝒛|k′,y)absent𝑝conditional𝒛superscript𝑘′𝑦\displaystyle=p(\bm{z}|k^{\prime},y) (38)
    ⇒I​(𝒛;k|y)=0.⇒absent𝐼𝒛conditional𝑘𝑦0\displaystyle\Rightarrow I(\bm{z};k|y)=0. (39)

Appendix D Proof of Proposition 3

By extending the information term between representations and clients conditioned on the labels, we have

I​(Z;K|Y)𝐼𝑍conditional𝐾𝑌\displaystyle\qquad I(Z;K|Y)
=∫Y∑k∈𝒦∫Zp​(k,y,𝒛)​log⁡p​(k,𝒛|y)p​(k|y)​p​(𝒛|y)​d​𝒛​d​yabsentsubscript𝑌subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑍𝑝𝑘𝑦𝒛𝑝𝑘conditional𝒛𝑦𝑝conditional𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦𝑑𝒛𝑑𝑦\displaystyle=\int_{Y}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\int_{Z}p(k,y,\bm{z})\log\frac{p(k,\bm{z}|y)}{p(k|y)p(\bm{z}|y)}d\bm{z}dy (40)
=∑k∈𝒦∫Y∫Zp​(k,y)​p​(𝒛|k,y)​log⁡p​(𝒛|k,y)p​(𝒛|y)​d​𝒛​d​y.absentsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦𝑑𝒛𝑑𝑦\displaystyle=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(k,y)p(\bm{z}|k,y)\log\frac{p(\bm{z}|k,y)}{p(\bm{z}|y)}d\bm{z}dy. (41)

Similarly, due to the intractable p​(𝒛|y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦p(\bm{z}|y), we use q​(𝒛|y)𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦q(\bm{z}|y) to approximate it. According to the fact that KL divergence is always positive, we have

DKL(p(Z|Y)||q(Z|Y))≥0\displaystyle D_{\text{KL}}(p(Z|Y)||q(Z|Y))\geq 0 (42)
⇒⇒\displaystyle\Rightarrow ∫Y∫Zp​(𝒛,y)​log​p​(𝒛|y)q​(𝒛|y)​𝑑𝒛​𝑑y≥0subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝒛𝑦log𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦0\displaystyle\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(\bm{z},y)\text{log}\frac{p(\bm{z}|y)}{q(\bm{z}|y)}d\bm{z}dy\geq 0 (43)
⇒⇒\displaystyle\Rightarrow ∑k∈𝒦∫Y∫Zp​(k,y,𝒛)​log⁡p​(𝒛|y)q​(𝒛|y)​d​𝒛​d​y≥0subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑘𝑦𝒛𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦𝑑𝒛𝑑𝑦0\displaystyle\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(k,y,\bm{z})\log\frac{p(\bm{z}|y)}{q(\bm{z}|y)}d\bm{z}dy\geq 0 (44)
⇒⇒\displaystyle\Rightarrow ∑k∈𝒦∫Y∫Zp​(k,y,𝒛)​log⁡p​(𝒛|y)​𝑑𝒛​𝑑ysubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑘𝑦𝒛𝑝conditional𝒛𝑦differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦\displaystyle\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(k,y,\bm{z})\log p(\bm{z}|y)d\bm{z}dy
≥∑k∈𝒦∫Y∫Zp​(k,y,𝒛)​log​q​(𝒛|y)​𝑑𝒛​𝑑y.absentsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑘𝑦𝒛log𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦differential-d𝒛differential-d𝑦\displaystyle\quad\quad\geq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(k,y,\bm{z})\text{log}q(\bm{z}|y)d\bm{z}dy. (45)

Then, we have

I​(Z,K|Y)𝐼𝑍conditional𝐾𝑌\displaystyle\qquad I(Z,K|Y)
≤∑k∈𝒦∫Y∫Zp​(k,y)​p​(𝒛|k,y)​log⁡p​(𝒛|k,y)q​(𝒛|y)​d​𝒛​d​yabsentsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦𝑑𝒛𝑑𝑦\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(k,y)p(\bm{z}|k,y)\log\frac{p(\bm{z}|k,y)}{q(\bm{z}|y)}d\bm{z}dy (46)
=∑k∈𝒦∫Yp​(k,y)​∫Zp​(𝒛|k,y)​log⁡p​(𝒛|k,y)q​(𝒛|y)​d​𝒛​d​y.absentsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑌𝑝𝑘𝑦subscript𝑍𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦𝑑𝒛𝑑𝑦\displaystyle=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\int_{Y}p(k,y)\int_{Z}p(\bm{z}|k,y)\log\frac{p(\bm{z}|k,y)}{q(\bm{z}|y)}d\bm{z}dy. (47)

Let m=p​(𝒛|k,y,𝒙)𝑚𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝒙m=p(\bm{z}|k,y,\bm{x}) and f​(m)=m​log⁡(m)​(m>0)𝑓𝑚𝑚𝑚𝑚0f(m)=m\log(m)(m>0). Since f​(m)𝑓𝑚f(m) is a convex function, according to the Jensen’s Inequality, we obtain:

p​(𝒛|k,y)​log⁡p​(𝒛|k,y)𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦\displaystyle p(\bm{z}|k,y)\log p(\bm{z}|k,y)
≤∫Xabsentsubscript𝑋\displaystyle\leq\int_{X} p​(𝒙|k,y)​p​(𝒛|k,y,𝒙)​log⁡p​(𝒛|k,y,𝒙).𝑝conditional𝒙𝑘𝑦𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝒙𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝒙\displaystyle p(\bm{x}|k,y)p(\bm{z}|k,y,\bm{x})\log p(\bm{z}|k,y,\bm{x}). (48)

By including it into equation (45), we get

I​(Z,K|Y)𝐼𝑍conditional𝐾𝑌\displaystyle\qquad I(Z,K|Y)
≤∑k∈𝒦∫X∫Y∫Zp​(k,𝒙,y,𝒛)​log⁡p​(𝒛|k,y,𝒙)q​(𝒛|y)​d​𝒛​d​y​d​𝒙absentsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑋subscript𝑌subscript𝑍𝑝𝑘𝒙𝑦𝒛𝑝conditional𝒛𝑘𝑦𝒙𝑞conditional𝒛𝑦𝑑𝒛𝑑𝑦𝑑𝒙\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\int_{X}\int_{Y}\int_{Z}p(k,\bm{x},y,\bm{z})\log\frac{p(\bm{z}|k,y,\bm{x})}{q(\bm{z}|y)}d\bm{z}dyd\bm{x} (49)
≤∑k∈𝒦p(k)𝔼p​(𝒙,y|k)DKL(p(𝒛|k,𝒙)∥q(𝒛|y))\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}p(k)\mathbb{E}_{p(\bm{x},y|k)}D_{\text{KL}}\big{(}p(\bm{z}|k,\bm{x})\|q(\bm{z}|y)\big{)} (50)
=ℒa​l​i​g​n.absentsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛\displaystyle=\mathcal{L}_{align}. (51)
